content: We're planning on scheduling our first meeting for the week of the 28th. With any luck whatever time we settle on for the first meeting will become our regular meeting time, initially scheduled once every two weeks. If you're interested in attending the meetings please add your availability to this doodle doc
https://doodle.com/poll/fkmvqvpq6eu68igi
if you have any issues with adding your availability let me know in this thread

we haven't discussed if we are going to do voice meetings (over zoom or something) or textual ones (on zulip). I would prefer the latter and it's easier for others to follow as well, but i'm open to both
A transcript of recordings would be nice.
I'd prefer text
text is nice because I can follow along as someone not in the working group :)
(#t-compiler is probably tired of me interrupting their discussions by now :laughing:)
So far its looking like the most popular time is monday at 11 am
tho this doesn't work for my other co-shepherd
also it looks like @Charles Ellis O'Riley Jr. voted twice
I'd like to setup some sort of agenda and minutes for the meeting
if anyone has recommendations of other wgs that have this figured out that I can refer to that would be appreciated
This may sound like I'm joking, but I encourage running the meetings with an iron fist.
No agenda == no meeting.
Infra uses a paper doc for the agenda.
s/with an iron fist/with well defined structure/
lol
structure that is actually enforced though. Without the follow-through it's meaningless.
And I know you know this, but to state this clearly for any other readers: it's your group and you decide what you want from it. But you asked for recommendations :-)
You can see our last meeting
You can have mandatory open time as well. :wink:
e.g. infra usually has a set duration meeting and if there's time at the end Pietro opens it up.
how long does infra have their meetings scheduled for?
Looks like 1hr
k cool, that's what I wanted to start with for this pg
I think I'm gonna default to hackmd.io because thats what the libs team uses
and they already gave me access to the libs team hackmd
well i've been on both sides of the fence
(deleted)

side 1: have a meeting regularly with or without agenda
side 2: have a meeting only when there's something to discuss
If you wanna get fancy you can do both. Alternate every other week, for example. All about what you want.
it becomes difficult to track things and to know if people are still in the group over time

reduced frequency might make sense if there's expected to be nothing to talk about, e.g. if the project gets blocked on something, but it should probably still happen now and then even if purely as a keepalive ping.
or 30-min fixed, 30-min free. The free effectively ends up being office hours
time-wise i think 30 mins should be sufficient
like if I was on a hypothetical wg-specialization and everyone went "sooo we're basically waiting on Chalk, right?" "yeah." "cool, let's have a seasonal meeting then."
Everything is blocked on chalk/polonius
"once every 12 weeks let's make sure no one got hit by a bus."
I know it's... a Thing.
Actually are those like, related essentially? Or is it just "they happen to share some implementation details"?
so my thinking was have the meeting regardless of if there's an agenda, and always prioritize the agenda
so if going over the agenda takes the full hour then thats it, if it ends early then we can discuss whatever or adjourn early
but meetings always end at the hour
i think 30 mins should be sufficient
I'd be okay with 30 if it was once a week, but the current plan is once every two weeks, so I'd prefer 1 hour
we can see how it goes though
I definitely think we should be flexible based on how the first couple meetings go

there is also likely to be more to talk about the first few times, probably, since... kickoff.
If you happen to need less time than an hour in the future then you can just scale down.
exactly
Jane, are you able to determine if someone was successful in signing up for the meeting?
I can see the list of ppl who've marked down their availability
not sure if you saw but I mentioned earlier that you seem to have entered your times twice @Charles Ellis O'Riley Jr.
just saying from past experience groups which reserved 1h at start and ended up at 30 :stuck_out_tongue: (we can always consider it 30 +30 emergency) but let's see how it goes
sounds good, ill definitely keep an eye on shortening the meeting
During the first meeting, you have everyone introduce themselves, tell two truths and a lie, and then what their favorite animal is. That can help eat up some time :wink:
or just pick the most controversial thread from this stream :stuck_out_tongue:
Remove Result / errors and replace them with {error codes, panics, closures}
@Jane Lusby looking at the doodle sheet so far, 2020-09-29T00:00:00+02:00 seems to be the best time where all the 3 shepherds are available and most of the sheep :sheep: members
let me double check the doodle rq
also, 3 shepherds?
afaik right now there's 2 shepherds + an advisor + a liason
let me recheck the initial github issue

also @DPC i've already talked to @Sean Chen about the 11 am timeslot that he marked maybe for, and he said that it should be fine, particularly given that we're doing the meeting in text rather than voice/video
so as far as I can tell 11 am is still the prime time slot
that's good then
sick
ty for helping with this btw
no worries :smile: happy to help
just to clarify and for benefit of others, it's the 18.00 UTC slot right? (2020-09-28T20:00:00+02:00)
correct
@**Ashley Mannix* isn't available at that time though so i hope that's fine
for one hour, I'll setup an agenda hackmd tomorrow I think and create a thread for it so people can start suggesting topics for the meeting
oh shit good point
okay in retrospect I think you're right
Its pretty important that our lib teams liason is able to make the meetings
so lets tenatively do 3pm PST / 22.00 UTC
Tuesday September 29? Lemme check my calendar and see why I'm not available... :upside_down:

@Ashley Mannix monday i think, let me double check

edit: yea, monday the 28th
To reduce confusion, I think it helps to use Zulip's time tag. It auto-converts to the local timezone of each participant: 2020-09-28T18:00:00-04:00
thats sick
how do you use that?
type <time and it will show a pop-up calendar time selector, and complete the tag for you
:thumbs_up:
I just learned it by viewing the source of @DPC 's comment here: https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/257204-project-error-handling/topic/Meeting.20Scheduling/near/210814453
okay so @Ashley Mannix the one you're unavailable for is 2020-09-28T11:00:00-07:00 and the one you are available for but which has 2 fewer people able to attend is 2020-09-28T15:00:00-07:00
Looks like you can type in ISO8601 directly too: <time:2020-09-29T08:00:00+10:00>
@Jane Lusby Ah, that first one I'm not available for is just because it's 4am local time for me, but that's ok :smile: I can make that time :+1:
:grimacing: you sure???
ah ye someone noticed it and posted it in #zulip so i normally use that and it's pretty neat :stuck_out_tongue:
Yep :smile: Chances are I'll be up anyways :laughter_tears:
I'll put it on the Libs calendar! Is that repeating every 2 weeks?
yes
does that send the calendar invite?
@DPC Oh I actually don't think I've posted a ICS for the Libs calendar yet. I'll add one to the readme and drop a link in here too for anybody that wants to subscribe to it
Done! Here's an ICS for the calendar: https://calendar.google.com/calendar/ical/9kuu8evq4eh6uacm262k0phri8%40group.calendar.google.com/public/basic.ics
It's also posted on the rust-lang/libs-team repo
Oops.. Might've picked the wrong day :|
Fixed :sweat_smile:
hypee
closing the doodle then :smile:
tyvm!
Is there a Google Calendar link for this?
yes, it's like 10 msgs back in the history
that's .ics though which doesn't work on non-apple devices (or does with some pain :grinning: )
I imported the Google Calendar invite into Google Calendar and I am not seeing a meeting place. Is that still TBD, or am I just missing it?
let me check the event
yea it didn't mark it down, the meeting place is zulip chat
we'll make sure to update it to note that
That makes it easy. Thanks!
There is a Libs team calendar, link on the GH
https://github.com/rust-lang/libs-team
(you can copy the invite to your calendar from there, just have to set the recurring part)
You can always put in a PR to have the README.md updated
I‚Äôll update the invite üôá‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
ok. I'm getting use to this Zulip app. I voted twice because I wasn't sure I did it corredtly the first time. In any event I'll be at the meeting on the 28th. I just need to know the time.

Jane Lusby said:

also it looks like Charles Ellis O'Riley Jr. voted twice

Sorry about voting twice. Just set up a time and I'll be there
the time is on the calendar, I'm sorry I haven't got back to u with it yet, I'm still on my phone and can't use the auto timezone localizing tag on this client
it's 11 am PST
Start time: 11 am PST is 1pm CST. Thanks

for clarity, because timezones can be really messy: (this will display the time in your timezone, so you don't have to worry about converting it)
The meeting is at 2020-09-28T20:00:00+02:00

Unfortunately, I'm not seeing a time zone conversion in the Zulip iOS app.

Instead, I see:

The meeting is at 2020-09-28T20:00:00+02:00

To check the conversion, look at the time zone (the "+02:00" part), and make sure it matches your local time zone.
Or convert from the UTC time, which is 2020-09-28 18:00:00 UTC.
ah didn't know about that. Reported it in #zulip

hey now I'm confused with what I seen on my zulip. (android app)

so if I see:

2020-09-28T20:00:00+02:00

means

a) meeting will be at 20h of the 28th in my local time.

b) I need to add X amount of time to the hours being X what follows after the plus sign

?
(deleted)
I'm not actually sure @Nelson J Morais , what timezone are you in?
right if was UTC I wasn't especting the +2 hours, and I would be confident in making the conversion.. that plus sign is making me nervous :sweat_smile:
I'm in Europe/Lisbon
same time as UK London

https://time.is/1800_28_Sept_2020_in_UTC
This URL will show you the meeting date/time in your local timezone (it should convert it from UTC)

I've logged in desktop and in fact the date is on my local time, i just need to figure it out what token/format DPC used for that :smile:
image.png
thanks @must-compute !
it's <time: @Nelson J Morais
on the desktop app typing that gives you a date popup box

ok, thanks Jane!
Yeah. on desktop it does the convertion, on Android Zulip app it doesn't.
Now that i know the exact time i'll try to show up to the meeting, lemme just find out that calendar/agenda url :smile:
you can also subscribe to the calendar event, and depending on the way your google calendar is set up you can get a reminder 30 mins in advance :smile:
